Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: High-Performance, Environmentally Friendly Polymer Systems for Paints and Coatings
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project is to provide the paint and coatings industry with new high-performance, cost-competitive polymer/resin systems that reduce solvent emissions and use of petrochemicals. In addition, these new polymer/resin systems enable one-component, ambient-cure coatings to be produced. This means that highly protective coatings can be produced without the need for mixing multiple components together prior to application or applying heat or light to cure the coatings. The one-component, ambient-cure features of these polymer/resin systems largely eliminate waste and energy costs associated with coating application and lend themselves to the production of paints and coatings that can be applied by the average person. Compared to the current state-of-the-art in one-component, ambient-cured resins, these new polymer/resin systems provide dramatically shorter drying times, dramatically better chemical resistance, and much higher film hardness, while exhibiting excellent impact resistance and flexibility. The highly desirable properties of these new cost-competitive polymer/resin systems will enable commercial success, while their low solvent emissions and high renewable content will reduce impact on the environment.

The objectives of this Phase II research project are to: 1) further optimize the polymer/resin systems to produce compositions that minimize solvent content and maximize performance, while meeting the cost constraints of the market; 2) put in place a pilot-line to provide potential customers with adequate sample sizes to enable their own evaluation of potential products, 3) generate weathering, corrosion, and storage/shelf stability data to further understand the application potential of optimized polymer/resin systems; and 4) optimize the polymer/resin production process to minimize cost and minimize production waste. By meeting these objectives, the Phase II project will result in the generation of new polymer/resin systems that will enable the development and commercialization of new paints and coatings that are one-component, ambient-cured, low in solvent content that exhibit exceptional properties, while being primarily based on renewable materials. Optimized polymer/resin systems will be provided to potential customers for their own internal evaluation. If necessary, feedback from customer evaluations will be used to modify polymer/resin system composition to meet customer needs. By the end of the Phase II project, the technology will be ready to proceed to manufacturing scale-up and product commercialization.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the project was to move the novel plant oil-based polymer (POBP) systems closer to commercialization.  Over the project performance period, the team's technical efforts have been focused on the following specific objectives of the Phase II project: 1) Optimize POBP system composition; 2) Conduct accelerating weathering and corrosion resistance testing; 3) Determine and maximize the shelf/storage stability; 4) Optimize polymerization processes to minimize cost and production waste; 5) Sample potential customers with select POBP systems 6) Receive customer feedback.
POBPs based on different comonomer systems were tested and their coating properties were compared to the performance of commercial alkyd resins, which are one of  the few commercial thermoset coatings enabling one-component coatings with curing at ambient conditions. The results of our testing showed that Renuvix POBPs produce coatings that exhibit dramatically shorter set-to-touch and tack-free time, exceptional impact resistance, substantially higher hardness/scratch resistance and better solvent/chemical resistance compared to commercial alkyds.
The weatherability of coatings based on POBPs was compared to a variety of coatings based on commercial alkyd resins.  The weathering results were consistent with the corrosion resistance results indicating that coatings based on POBPs that exhibit best coating properties may only be useful for indoor applications. Some POBP coatings provide exceptional corrosion resistance when applied onto a steel substrate, however, they require complex purification from residual monomers which is not feasible on a production scale.
The effect of temperature on the shelf life of POBPs and controls based on commercial alkyds was determined in our laboratory trials. Initial testing resulted in a faster increase in viscosity compared to the controls and significant aging when POBPs heated above 50 ?C. In later studies, reasonable stability was achieved by reducing the molecular weight of the POBP during the synthesis.
As a result of process optimization studies, kinetic trials were conducted to determine polymerization parameters for most promising POBP systems. Scalable semi-batch polymerization protocols were established that allowed control over the polymerization kinetics and POBP yield. The complete consumption of monomers was achieved for the POBP system that showed the best performance, however, another monomer system resulted in low polymer yield.
A pilot reactor was assembled and used for the production of multi-kilogram quantities of the plant-oil based monomers and new POBPs. Samples of optimized POBP systems along with all technical documentation were produced and provided to potential customers.

Intellectual Merit
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project has resulted in the utilization of a fundamentally different synthesis method for the production of one-component ambient cured resins similar to alkyds. The polymerization technique developed for producing POBPs is readily scalable and widely used in commercial large-scale production of polymeric materials, however, to the best of our knowledge, the polymerization method has never been used in the production of commercial ambient-cured coatings. The process developed is also applicable to monomers based on plant oils from different sources and was proven for successful polymerization of polyunsaturated-fatty acid-based monomers as well as fully saturated fatty acid-based monomers.
Also the Phase II SBIR grant has resulted in the development of new POBP systems that enable new coating materials that are one-component, ambient-cured, low in volatile organic compound (VOC) content that exhibit exceptional properties while being primarily based on renewable materials.  Compared to commercial alkyd coatings, which are one of the few thermoset coatings that can enable one-component coatings that cure at ambient conditions, the POBP-based coatings exhibited dramatically shorter drying time, far better solvent/chemical resistance, and substantially higher hardness/scratch resistance, without sacrificing flexibility and impact resistance. These features combined with the low environmental impact associated with low VOC content and high biobased content provide very good value to the customer and society in general.

Broader Impacts
Renuvix high-performance plant oil bases polymeric systems (POBPs) that were developed under the USDA Phase II project are largely biobased and derived from abundant, rapidly renewable and low-cost soybean oil. Thus, it is expected that new coatings based on POBPs are substantially better for the environment and human health.  In addition, the one-component coatings that cure at ambient conditions provide the added environmental benefits by eliminating waste associated with the use of two-component systems and the energy costs associated with thermally-cured coating systems. Also, it has been shown that uncured POBPs are readily biodegradable which supports the expectation of reduced environmental impact at the end of the product lifecycle. Besides the significant environmental benefits and advantages over existing technologies for producing polymeric coating products, the developed technology showed the ability to provide the coatings industry with new high-performance, cost-competitive polymer systems.
From the production aspect, the developed technology increases demand in renewable ingredients for the POBPs such as soybean oil or its derivatives. This lessens the coating market dependence on petrochemicals, opens new revenues for US farmers and US soy processors.


Last Modified: 11/27/2019
Modified by: Ihor Tarnavchyk

Over the project performance period, the team's technical efforts have been focused on the following specific objectives of the Phase II project: 1) Optimize POBP system composition; 2) Conduct accelerating weathering and corrosion resistance testing; 3) Determine and maximize the shelf/storage stability; 4) Optimize polymerization processes to minimize cost and production waste; 5) Sample potential customers with select POBP systems 6) Receive customer feedback. The results of our testing showed that Renuvix POBPs produce coatings that exhibit dramatically shorter set-to-touch and tack-free time, exceptional impact resistance, substantially higher hardness/scratch resistance and better solvent/chemical resistance compared to commercial alkyds. The weatherability of coatings based on POBPs was compared to a variety of coatings based on commercial alkyd resins. The weathering results were consistent with the corrosion resistance results indicating that coatings based on POBPs that exhibit best coating properties may only be useful for indoor applications. Some POBP coatings provide exceptional corrosion resistance when applied onto a steel substrate, however, they require complex purification from residual monomers which is not feasible on a production scale. Thus, it is expected that new coatings based on POBPs are substantially better for the environment and human health. Also, it has been shown that uncured POBPs are readily biodegradable which supports the expectation of reduced environmental impact at the end of the product lifecycle. Besides the significant environmental benefits and advantages over existing technologies for producing polymeric coating products, the developed technology showed the ability to provide the coatings industry with new high-performance, cost-competitive polymer systems. From the production aspect, the developed technology increases demand in renewable ingredients for the POBPs such as soybean oil or its derivatives.
